fields.label_text:
FRAGMENT OF A HAND KNOTTED CAUCASIAN CARPET in which the pile has worn away, creating an opportunity to see the underlying structure.  

Cream/light brown woollen warp threads, which run the length of the carpet,  interlace with horizontal white cotton weft crossing over one weft thread and under the next to form plain weave. 

The warp is clearly visible along the tear in the centre of the piece: three woollen threads of slightly different shades have been plied (twisted) together to form each warp thread. This colour effect is sometimes known as a 'barber's pole' and in a technical analysis the warp threads would be described as 'Z3S',  meaning that two threads spun anti-clockwise have been twisted together in a clockwise direction to create a strong and useable thread. 

The weft is also visible in this area and because it is cotton it has a slightly fluffy appearance when compared with wool.  Loose weft threads can be seen along the lower edge of the fragment showing how undulating the weft is as it passes over and under the warp threads. 

The pile was built up row by row with a line of knots, each tied around two warp threads, followed by two passes of weft which keep the knots in place and create a stable and very durable fabric.

Before it was acquired by the Museum attempts had been made to replace the missing pile with embroidery. There are embroidered repairs, mainly in pink, yellow and dark blue, in the lower right hand diagonal of the central lozenge.

 
Technical Analysis

WARP: cream and brown wool plied together; Z3S, two cream and one brown; 18 threads per inch (63 per dm).

WEFT: white cotton; Z3S; 2 shoots after every row of knots; 10 knots per inch (40 per dm).

PILE: wool; 11 colours: red, orange, yellow, dark green, light green, dark blue, light blue, dark brown (corroded), light brown, black, cream; plus small amount of olive embroidery to replace corroded dark brown, with some pink/green embroidery; symmetrical knot tied around 2 threads; 90 knots per sq. inch (1260 per sq. dm).

Woven in Azerbaijan between about 1880 and 1910.
T.49-1975

fields.descriptive_line: Fragment of hand knotted carpet of cotton and wool, Caucasus, 19th century.
fields.physical_description:
Carpet fragment of hand knotted wool and cotton.

WARP: cream and brown wool plied together; Z3S; two cream and one brown; 18 threads per inch (63 per dm).

WEFT: white cotrton; Z3S, possibly two cotton and one wool; 2 shoots after every row of knots; 10 knots per inch (40 per dm).

PILE: wool; 11 colours: red, orange, yellow , dark green, light green, dark blue, light blue, dark brown (corroded), light brown, black, cream; plus small amount of olive embroidery to replace corroded dark brown, with some pink/green embroidery; symmetrical knot tied around 2 threads; 90 knots per sq. inch (1260 per sa. dm.)

SIDE FINISH: incomplete.  Wefts cut and outer guard stripe missing.  Blue cord seam onto raw edge and oversewn.

END FINISH: cut

DESIGN: Field:  dark blue ground with central six-sided, blue medallion bordered with blocks containing flowerheads, with an outer, stepped border of red/green squares.  There are geometric motifs, blossoms and S motifs in the field and part of two hooked, multi-coloured diamonds in the upper part.

Main border: white ground with a curved, overlapping motif - each in a different colour.

Inner border: yellow S motif on red

Outer border: red S motif on light blue.

fields.production_note:
Retirement gift from Mr. Benardout of the Anglo-Persian Carpet Co., S. Kensington:
Part of a carpet, Caucasian (Moghan), 19th c. 
 "I write to thank you most cordially for your kindness in allowing the Museum to select from your stock such carpet freagments as will be useful for teaching purposes and for showing designs so far unrepresented in our collection."
